article:
. (Found with or without the letter [[G]])]]


'Freemasonry' is a that traces its origins to the loose organisation of medieval
Stonemasonry. Douglas Knoop, G.P. Jones, The Genesis of Freemasonry: An
Account of the Rise and Development of Freemasonry in its Operative, Accepted,
and Early Speculative Phases. Manchester. Manchester University Press.
1947. Early organizational forms included "lodges," incorporations, and
craft guilds. Douglas Knoop, G.P. Jones, The Genesis of Freemasonry: An
Account of the Rise and Development of Freemasonry in its Operative, Accepted,
and Early Speculative Phases. Manchester. Manchester University Press. 1947. pp.
38. Early Freemasonry based on craft labour is known as Operative
Freemasonry, while the modern, more philosophical form of Freemasonry is known
as Speculative Freemasonry.

Freemasonry now exists in various forms all over the world, with a membership
estimated by the United Grand Lodge of England at around six million
worldwide. {{cite web |url= http://www.ugle.org.uk/what-is-masonry/frequently-asked-
questions// |title= Frequently Asked Questions |publisher= United Grand Lodge of
England |accessdate= 2009-09-28 }} The fraternity is administratively organis ed into independent Grand Lodges (or sometimes Grand Orients),
each of which governs its own Masonic jurisdiction, which consists of
subordinate (or constituent) Lodges. The largest single jurisdiction, in terms
of membership, is the United Grand Lodge of England (with a membership estimated
at around a quarter million). The Grand Lodge of Scotland and Grand Lodge of
Ireland (taken together) have approximately 150,000 members. In the United States total membership is
just under two million. Hodapp, Christopher. Freemasons for Dummies.
Indianapolis: Wiley, 2005. p. 52.

The various Grand Lodges recognise each otherâor do notâbased upon adherence to
landmarks. A Grand Lodge will usually deem other Grand Lodges who share common
landmarks to be regular, and those that do not to be "irregular" or
"clandestine".

There are also numerous appendant bodies, which are organis ations related to the main branch of Freemasonry, but with their own
independent administration.
